chunks.content:
Driver Manual (Night, Street, and School Drivers)

Overview
Drivers at Driscoll Foods are responsible for delivering products safely, efficiently, and accurately to our customers. Drivers serve as the face of the company and are essential to operations. Driscoll Foods employs:

Street Drivers – Handle customer deliveries in NYC and surrounding areas

School Drivers – Deliver to schools with strict schedules and fines for errors

Helper Drivers – Assist main drivers with loading/unloading and case management

Tractor-Trailer Drivers – Handle long-haul deliveries, transfers, and backhauls

Every driver must adhere to company safety policies, DOT regulations, and delivery schedules, ensuring products arrive in excellent condition and on time.

Shift Times & Flexibility

Street Drivers (NYC): Start times vary, typically 3:00 AM for Manhattan or 5:00 AM for other NYC routes

School Drivers: Start earlier (around 2:30–3:00 AM) to ensure on-time delivery by school deadlines

Helper Drivers: Follow assigned drivers’ schedules

Tractor-Trailer Drivers: Start times vary depending on routes, pickups, and backhauls

End-of-Shift: Drivers finish when all deliveries, backhauls, and paperwork are complete, which varies daily

DOT Compliance: All drivers must follow hours-of-service regulations, including mandatory rest breaks, driving limits, and accurate logging in electronic logging devices (ELDs)

Clock-In & Pre-Route Preparation

Clock in at the waiting area upon arrival

Obtain all necessary route documents from the dispatcher:

Loading sheets

Customer invoices

Keydrop forms and keys

E-jack batteries (if applicable)

Review the loading report:

Confirms number of cases per stop

Differentiates refrigerated, frozen, and dry products

Identifies special instructions, such as keydrop deliveries or time-sensitive school deliveries

Verify assigned truck/trailer and route ID in Omnitracs

Inspect vehicle and equipment:

E-jacks, handtrucks, straps, blankets, pallets

Confirm battery and vehicle readiness
synthetic_questions: What are the typical start times for school drivers?
How do I clock in and get my route documents from the dispatcher?
What do I need to review in the loading report for keydrop deliveries?
Omnitracs isn't showing my assigned truck or route ID—what do I do?
Walk me through the full pre-route prep, from clock-in to vehicle inspection including ELD logging.
chunks.quality_reasoning: Compliance-critical with safety, DOT regs, and core driver procedures; bounded to company driver roles and prep steps; basic training level; self-contained for overview and pre-route actions; highly actionable checklists.

school_driver_start_time.context: School Drivers start to meet strict school deadlines

street_driver_other_nyc_start.context: Typical start for other NYC routes

chunks.content:
Ensure DOT compliance: check hours available for driving, inspect vehicle for roadworthiness, and confirm all required safety equipment is onboard

Loading & Route Setup

Organize truck according to route layout:

Last stops go to the nose of the truck, first stops go to the tail

Refrigerated, frozen, and dry sections are clearly separated

Pallets are secured, strapping taller pallets if necessary

Review route-specific instructions:

Keydrop instructions, arrival time windows, school delivery times

Adjust loading to ensure quick unloading and minimal handling

Helper coordination:

Assign refrigerated/frozen items to the helper

Assign dry items to the driver for maximum efficiency

Check route against invoices: ensure all pallets are present and match route requirements

Delivery Procedures
Street Deliveries

Follow loading sheet and invoices to deliver products to each stop

Check labels AND case product names to prevent mispicks

Use handtrucks and e-jacks efficiently, placing items in correct customer locations

Keydrop deliveries: ensure codes are followed, lock doors, and photograph deliveries for proof

Mark all delivered items on the front sheet of the invoice

Maintain professional customer interactions; courteous, patient behavior is critical

Follow time windows; do not arrive too early or late

School Deliveries

Must adhere to strict delivery schedules, often by 2:00 PM for NYC schools

Deliveries include case counts, frozen, refrigerated, and dry products

Schools are subject to fines for missing cases ($500 per case)

Be patient and courteous with school staff; handle challenges calmly

Verify deliveries by marking on invoices and obtaining staff confirmation

Tractor-Trailer Deliveries & Backhauls

Handle long-haul deliveries to other Driscoll Foods locations or customer warehouses

Transfers may require relinking trailers or picking up backhaul products

Maintain correct routing for backhauls, ensuring trucks return full to maximize efficiency

Follow all safety protocols, secure loads, and track truck positions accurately in Omnitracs
synthetic_questions: What do I need to check for DOT compliance before hitting the road?
How do I load the truck so last stops are at the nose and first at the tail?
What's the exact procedure for keydrop deliveries, including photos?
Schools have that $500 fine per missing case—how do I verify and mark deliveries to avoid it?
Helper loaded dry stuff in the reefer and now pallets don't match invoices—what a mess, how do I fix this?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Covers DOT compliance, safety, and core delivery processes critical for drivers; specific to trucking operations with clear steps, self-contained for procedures but assumes basic domain terms.

jargon.DOT compliance: Adherence to Department of Transportation regulations including hours of service and vehicle safety
jargon.hours available for driving: Regulatory limit on driver hours under DOT rules
jargon.roadworthiness: Vehicle condition suitable for safe road operation
jargon.keydrop instructions: Guidelines for unattended deliveries using access codes or keys
jargon.keydrop deliveries: Unsupervised product drops at locked locations with photo proof
jargon.handtrucks: Manual wheeled carts for moving loads
jargon.backhauls: Return loads picked up after delivery to maximize truck utilization
jargon.Omnitracs: Telematics system for tracking truck positions and routes

fine_per_missing_case.context: Penalty for schools on undelivered cases

chunks.content:
Safety & Compliance

All drivers must adhere to DOT regulations, including:

Maximum driving hours

Required rest breaks

Accurate log entries in ELDs

Maintain safe driving practices:

No hard braking, aggressive acceleration, or distracted driving

Use seatbelts and follow traffic laws

Follow company safety protocols:

Check pallets for stability

Use handtrucks, e-jacks, and straps safely

Report any accidents or near-misses immediately

End-of-Shift Procedures

Return to warehouse after completing deliveries, transfers, and backhauls

Park assigned truck/trailer at designated loading doors

Return equipment:

Handtrucks

E-jack batteries

Straps and blankets

Complete paperwork:

Undelivered cases, damages, or mispicks

Route confirmations and backhaul updates

Clock out once all tasks are complete

Performance & Incentives

Drivers are paid hourly plus potential incentives for productivity

Accuracy and efficiency are critical; mispicks or delayed deliveries impact bonuses

Netradyne cameras monitor driving behavior and contribute to driver scores

Following DOT and company procedures ensures safety, reliability, and full incentive eligibility

Key Takeaways

Drivers must balance speed, efficiency, and accuracy

Proper route preparation and equipment use are critical to completing deliveries safely

Customer interaction is vital; drivers represent Driscoll Foods professionally

All activities must comply with DOT regulations and company safety policies

Flexibility is essential; shift end depends on completion of all deliveries and paperwork
synthetic_questions: What do I have to do at the end of my shift before clocking out?
What if I have a near-miss while driving—do I need to report it?
How do I ensure accurate log entries in my ELD to stay DOT compliant?
I finished all my deliveries and backhauls but can't clock out—what am I missing with the paperwork?
How does Netradyne camera footage impact my driver score and incentive pay?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Compliance-critical safety and DOT regulations, core driver procedures; clear, actionable steps for daily operations; self-contained with lists and key takeaways

jargon.backhauls: Return trips with cargo from customer or vendor back to warehouse
jargon.mispicks: Incorrectly picked or selected items for delivery
jargon.Netradyne cameras: Driver monitoring camera system for behavior scoring
